reviewText:
Duke Nukem 3D's sister game. It shares many similarities to Duke3D, though it plays completely different. Rather than carefully balancing ammo like in Duke, this game tries the opposite and makes health extremely scarce, but gives you a ton of super powerful weapons with huge amounts of ammo. To put it in perspective my most used gun in this game is the rocket launcher rather than the shotgun like most old games. Be sure to save often if you play this as being killed with 100 health is not terribly uncommon. The game in general is significantly more difficult than Duke as well (except Duke episode 4).

MP is also pretty entertaining, or at least was back in the day. Good luck getting a DM together now.

7/10

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is a classic first person shooter made by 3D Realms back in the 90s. It was effectively the successor to Duke Nukem 3D. While Duke Nukem 3D made fun of American action movies, Shadow Warrior was a parody on Kung Fu movies.

The game stars Lo Wang, a man who continuously makes puns about how his name is slang for ♥♥♥♥♥. Who's mentor is killed by his arch nemesis, which prompts Lo Wang to go on a roaring rampage of revenge across a fairly lengthy campaign.

The thing with Shadow Warrior I tend to dislike is more it's reliance on enemies with hitscan weapons. The most common footsoldier in the game is your basic ninja with an uzi, and he drains your health pretty quickly win an undodgeable barrage of bullets. In contrast the basic trooper in Duke Nukem 3D fired a slow moving projectile you could dodge. I actually never finished this game entirely because of how unforgiving it was.

Add to that it's stylistic influence was a bit campy and in general the game wasn't as well polished as Duke 3D was. It ran on the same engine though and had a source port so that's a plus.

One thing to note about the Steam release is it runs on Dosbox, so unlike the Duke Nukem 3D Megaton edition it will not run in your native resolution or anything. So I'd suggest seeking out a sourceport which there are a good amount of for this game.

Product received for free\n\nGreat classic FPS from 3D Realms, runs really well on my PC, but I use my Mac for school and like to play classic games like this in my spare time on it, but unfortunately it runs terribly, and games like Half Life 2, Quake III and CS 1.6 and even Morrowind all run at 50 or 60 FPS (CS 1.6 runs at 80). I don't know why it's like this, but otherwise, the game is great, but not for those who just want a Doom I or II experience, it's not a run and gun killfest, you really have to take it slow and think a lot of the time, sometimes being stuck in one level for 15 or 20 minutes (just like 3D Realms previous games, Blood and Duke Nukem 3D (which really needs to be on Steam, but you can get eDuke32 and run it at 1280x800)). If you were annoyed after a bad day at school or work, this game would just ♥♥♥♥ you off with it's sometimes overly complex linear level design, brutally unforgiving difficulty and unfortunately, sometimes underpowered weapons like the riot shotgun that reminds me more of a Nerf gun than a shotgun. Other than that, the game still looks cool and has a lot of charm, as does any 3D Realms game really, the protagonist is hilarious, maybe even more so than Duke Nukem himself. The enemies are your generis old school FPS carbon copy Doom clones, the weapons are half good half terrible but for what the game lacks in creativity, it makes up for in overall charm. I would recommened this if you have a PC, but if you're wanting to play it on Mac, i wouldn't even try, it's so poorly optimized it may as well not exist.
